instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN: What is EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN? EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN is necessary to enable the power rail that powers the LCD screen image circuitry. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.SMC_LID_LEFT: What is SMC_LID_LEFT? SMC_LID_LEFT is a signal that tells the system if the lid is closed from the left LID sensor. If it is low, the system thinks the lid is closed â€“ if it is 3.3v, the system thinks the machine is open. SMC_LID_LEFT needs to be high for the machine to stay awake and have a backlight. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no pictures/backlight - Symptoms for a bad Mux chip?
threads.message:
Hi,

We have a test <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> mainboard that we use for test and we did plug our customer screen to it for testing, after a small liquid damage on his screen.
Backlight wasn't shorted but anyhow, no picture/backlight on his screen and then on our test screen as well after that.

I saw Paul lately replacing a Mux chip on the same board model after getting no picture and I was wondering what I should check before going that route.

Thanks!

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no pictures/backlight - Symptoms for a bad Mux chip?
threads.message:
Mainboard should get protected against bad LCD assembly.
Unless you've plugged in some corroded connector; check if is the case.
Inspect all the connectors from the client LCD assembly.

Do you get image, missing only backlight?
Also test USB activity.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no pictures/backlight - Symptoms for a bad Mux chip?
threads.message:
I am not getting a picture from what I can tell.
I am getting external display working using HDMI adapter.

LCD assembly had liquid damage. The cable going from the mainboard to the LCD board has green stuff.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no pictures/backlight - Symptoms for a bad Mux chip?
threads.message:
What board do you have there?
820-xxxx code please...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no pictures/backlight - Symptoms for a bad Mux chip?
threads.message: It's a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no pictures/backlight - Symptoms for a bad Mux chip?
threads.message: Change <CHIP>U9850</CHIP>, it protects CPU DP outputs.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no pictures/backlight - Symptoms for a bad Mux chip?
threads.message:
Well I just did and same thing.
I've tried 3 different screens to rule out the screen issue but no difference.
I am still able to get a picture over HDMI though (USB-C adapter)

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no pictures/backlight - Symptoms for a bad Mux chip?
threads.message:
Check 3V3/<SIGNAL>5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> presence at LCD connector.
Also post <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD_R</SIGNAL> and voltage for pins 2, 12, 3, 6, 10 of <CHIP>U8510</CHIP>.
LCD assembly MUST be connected!

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no pictures/backlight - Symptoms for a bad Mux chip?
threads.message:
While battery is being not plugged, I am getting the sign on the screen that battery is low.
So assuming that...

Once I plug the charger:

<SIGNAL>3V3_SOSW_LCD</SIGNAL> will spike at 3.3V for a second
<SIGNAL>5V_SOSW_LCD</SIGNAL> will spike at 3.3V for a second

<SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD_R</SIGNAL> will spike at 3.3V for a second

<SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> will spike at 3.3V for a second
PANEL_FET__EN_DLY will spike at 3.3V for a second
<SIGNAL>DFR_DISP_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> will stay at 3.3V
<SIGNAL>DFR_DISP_SMC_RST_L</SIGNAL> will stay at 3.3V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> will stay at 3.3V

EDIT: backlight is created and measures 40V for a fraction of a second.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no pictures/backlight - Symptoms for a bad Mux chip?
threads.message:
Do you get the low battery sign on internal LCD?
That means the video circuit is OK.
Do you still get external video?

Check what happens disconnecting touchbar.
Also monitor <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_LID_LEFT</SIGNAL>/RIGHT signals.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no pictures/backlight - Symptoms for a bad Mux chip?
threads.message:
Sorry my explanation was unclear. I am getting the "low battery" sign on the external display only, not the internal display.

While testing, I am using only the logicboard and our test screen. (test screen has been tested working fine with another 2017 board)

As I know I am supposed to the the "low battery" sign, I am also supposed to see the screen turning on but it won't.
It seems the screen is being told to turn on and the voltage for the backlight is sent but for a fraction of a second.
There might be an issue between the mainboard and the screen to communicate somehow.

I will check <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> tomorrow but there was no issue in the past on this board, that was our test board which was working until I've plugged a customer bad screen and the internal display never turned on again since.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no pictures/backlight - Symptoms for a bad Mux chip?
threads.message:
If the backlight is created, even for short time, means LCD is recognized by PCH.
Did you try full LCD assembly?
Is it compatible for sure?
Try another one, just in case.

External video is stable?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no pictures/backlight - Symptoms for a bad Mux chip?
threads.message:
I have tried that same screen with a 2017 board model and it works just fine. It is a full assembly.
2016 and 2017 screens are supposed to be the same and compatible with both boards. Anyway, that was the original screen which worked fine previously with that board.
External video is stable enough to show me the "low battery" for 2-3 seconds as usual.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no pictures/backlight - Symptoms for a bad Mux chip?
threads.message:
As I've said earlier I've tried 3 different assembly which worked with another board so the assemblies are fine.

I can see the screen lighting up quickly (backlight turning on the screen) for a fraction of a second and off.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no pictures/backlight - Symptoms for a bad Mux chip?
threads.message:
Reflow/resolder <CHIP>U9850</CHIP>, maybe need to try another...
Maybe <CHIP>U9800</CHIP> was affected too, but is not usual.
Monitor all <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> signals, just in case.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no pictures/backlight - Symptoms for a bad Mux chip?
threads.message:
You got it... That was a bad donor <CHIP>U9850</CHIP> or my bad soldering ;-)
Fixed with installing another <CHIP>U9850</CHIP>.

Thanks!
